headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I'll be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Analog Devices First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I'll be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Analog Devices First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Ali Husain, Treasurer and Director of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, good morning. Thanks, Jennifer and good morning everyone. Thanks for joining ADI's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. You can find our press release, relating financial schedules and our investor toolkit at investor.analog.com. As usual, I'm
componenttext:
All right, good morning. Thanks, Jennifer and good morning everyone. Thanks for joining ADI's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. You can find our press release, relating financial schedules and our investor toolkit at investor.analog.com. 
As usual, I'm joined this morning by ADI's CEO, Vincent Roche; ADI's CFO Dave Zinsner. The format for today's call will be slightly different. Today's prepared remarks will be relatively short because we want to devote most of the call to Q&A. 
So before we start, let's get through some disclosures. Please note the information we're about to discuss, including our objectives and outlook includes forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including those discussed in our earnings release and our most recent 10-Q. 
These forward-looking statements reflect our opinion as of the date of this call. And we undertake no obligation to update these forward-looking statements in light of new information or future events. 
Our comments today will also include non-GAAP financial measures, which we've reconciled to their most directly comparable GAAP financial measures in today's earnings release, which we've posted at investor.analog.com. 
So with all that behind us, let's get started. 
So as you've likely seen, revenue in the first quarter totaled $769 million, which is about even to the same period in the prior year. Compared to the prior quarter, revenue decreased 21% but this sequential revenue performance masked what was really a tale of 2 narratives. 
While weakness in the consumer portable sector exacerbated what is typical seasonal weakness within the consumer market, our business-to-business, or B2B, markets of industrial, automotive and communications infrastructure combined to perform in line with our expectations. 
So let me give you a little color in our performance. The industrial market at 45% of revenue, decreased 5% sequentially during the seasonally weaker first quarter, which was a good result in a challenging macro environment. Compared to the prior year, the industrial market was stable. 
The automotive market at 16% of revenue, decreased 4% sequentially, with all sectors flat to down and in line with seasonal patterns. As compared to the same period in the prior year, revenue from ADAS, or Advanced Driver Assistance Systems, increased 22%; Powertrain Tech revenue grew 8%; and Infotainment sector revenue increased 6%. 
Turning now to Communications Infrastructure. Revenue in this market increased 4% sequentially, which was well ahead of seasonal patterns. Revenue from both wireless and wireline infrastructure customers increased sequentially as we believe the trough in the wireless market turns into the nascent recovery. As compared to the prior year, wireless revenues decreased while revenue from wireline customers increased. In total, ADI's B2B markets decreased 3% sequentially. 
Now in the consumer market. Revenues decreased 60% sequentially to $126 million and this market represented 16% of sales. While prosumer audiovideo applications decreased in line with seasonal patterns, revenue from portable consumer applications declined significantly as a result of weaker than forecasted customer demand in this sector after a prior quarter performance that have far exceeded expectations. 
So now I'll turn the call over to Dave for details of our financial performance in 1Q '16. With the exception of revenue, Dave's comments in our first quarter P&L line items will exclude special items, which in the aggregate, totaled $22 million for the quarter. When comparing our first quarter performance to our historical performance, special items are also excluded from prior quarter and year-over-year results. And reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP measures are included on Schedule E in today's release. So Dave, over to you.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ali. The first quarter was a challenging quarter as we executed through weaker economic conditions and significant weakness in the portable consumer electronic sector. Nevertheless, our B2B markets combined performed in line with our expectations
componenttext:
Thanks, Ali. The first quarter was a challenging quarter as we executed through weaker economic conditions and significant weakness in the portable consumer electronic sector. Nevertheless, our B2B markets combined performed in line with our expectations and we repurchased $132 million of our shares in response to stock price volatility, which helped reduce our share count by approximately 1%. 
Revenue in the first quarter totaled $769 million and diluted earnings per share was $0.56. Gross margin of 62.2% decreased 350 basis points from the prior quarter, primarily on higher inventory reserves and lower utilization rates. Inventory on a dollars basis decreased $7 million sequentially. And on a days basis, was 128 days on lower sales. 
Utilization rates in the first quarter were in the mid-50s and we are planning to increase utilization to the high 60s in the second quarter. Weeks of inventory and distribution were approximately 7.5 weeks, consistent with the prior quarter. 
Operating expenses of approximately $265 million declined to $27 million or 9% sequentially and were flat to the prior year as we continue to carefully manage expenses. Operating profit before tax of $214 million were 27.8% of sales, decreased from both the prior quarter and the year-ago period. Other expense was approximately $10 million as we raised $1.25 billion in 10 and 30 year notes. We expect our net interest expense for the remainder of fiscal 2016 to be approximately $15 million per quarter. 
Our first quarter tax rate was approximately 13%, which we expect will be our tax rate for the remainder of fiscal 2016. Excluding special items, diluted earnings per share was $0.56, which was a decrease of 11% as compared to the prior year on higher inventory reserves and interest expense. Nevertheless, our strong financial model continued to generate solid cash flows, which we use to enhance shareholder returns. Excluding a one-time payment relating to the conversion of our IRS pension plan, over the past 12 months, ADI has generated free cash flow of $1 billion or 30% of sales and we have returned $800 million to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks. 
The first quarter was also a strong working capital quarter, during which free cash flow as a percent of revenue increased to 26%, up from 19% in the prior year, which is an increase of approximately 700 basis points. Capital additions in the first quarter were $23 million or 3% of revenue and we are planning for capital additions in 2016 to be in the range of $130 million to $150 million. In line with our capital allocation strategy, our Board of Directors approved a $0.02 increase in the quarterly dividend to $0.42 per share, which is payable on March 8, 2016. This dividend represents the 13th dividend increase in the last 12 years. At the current stock price, our dividend yield is approximately 3.2%. Our board also increased the authorization under our stock repurchase program to $1 billion as we plan to continue to repurchase our stock during periods of stock price volatility. 
We ended the quarter with a cash and short-term investment balance of $3.8 billion, with approximately $1.2 billion available domestically. We had approximately $1.7 billion in debt outstanding, which resulted in a net cash position of $2.1 billion. 
Now turning to our outlook for the second quarter, which with the exception of revenue expectations is on a non-GAAP basis. And exclude special items, they're outlined in today's release. While we are cautious about the macroeconomic environment, current order trends in the industrial, automotive and communications infrastructure markets suggest combined sequential revenue growth in these B2B markets to be in the mid to high single digits in the second quarter. 
In consumer, we are expecting another quarter of sequential weakness within the portable sector of this market. In the aggregate, we're planning for revenue in the second quarter to be in the range of minus 2% to plus 4% sequentially. Gross margins are expected to increase to approximately 65.5% in the second quarter on higher utilization, a more favorable mix and lower expected inventory reserves as compared to the first quarter. We estimate that operating expenses will be up slightly in the second quarter. And as a result, for operating margins to expand sequentially. 
Based on these estimates and excluding any special items, diluted earnings per share are planned to be in the range of $0.58 to $0.66, which at the midpoint would represent an 11% sequential increase in EPS. 
We are currently operating at the lower end of our financial leverage model range and we are carefully managing production levels and operating expenses. As business conditions improve, we should drive better operating leverage. Overall, we estimate that we have approximately 800 basis points of operating leverage remaining in our financial model based on our first quarter exit rates. 
While near-term market headlines warrant caution, we believe our future prospects remain strong. We have been deepening and broadening our customer engagements while investing in our most critical technology vectors to support our long-term growth. And together with our operating model, these place ADI on a strong platform to achieve up to $5 in non-GAAP earnings by 2020. 
And so now I'll turn the call back over to Ali.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ambrish Srivastava from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ambrish Srivastava from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a long-term question on the automotive section for [indiscernible] Vince looking to answer. Auto has been a great business for you long term. Last year, last fiscal year, you didn't grow. Can you help us -- sorry, [indiscernible] room. Can you help
componenttext: I have a long-term question on the automotive section for [indiscernible] Vince looking to answer. Auto has been a great business for you long term. Last year, last fiscal year, you didn't grow. Can you help us -- sorry, [indiscernible] room. Can you help us understand where the business is positioned in some of the newer areas such as ADAS, self-driving [indiscernible] safety. So in the sense, what drove the business in the last 5 years and what should we be looking at in the future? Thank you.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, Ambrish, our automotive business has 3 major components to it: One is the Infotainment sector, which is largely built around audio and media products; we have a strong Powertrain business, which in the past number of years has really been drive
componenttext: Yes, well, Ambrish, our automotive business has 3 major components to it: One is the Infotainment sector, which is largely built around audio and media products; we have a strong Powertrain business, which in the past number of years has really been driven really by our strength in battery monitoring and control; and last but not least, the safety business, which has 3 major components, passive safety and active safety which are largely MEMS-based activities and advanced driver assistance. Now I can tell you that all those sectors grew over the last several years. The Infotainment area has grown in the high single digits. Same thing with the Powertrain business. And where we went into headwinds really is on the MEMS side of the safety business. The advanced driver assistance piece, in fact, has been growing at a rate of about 20% over the last 2 or 3 years. And in the MEMS area specifically, we have been very careful to exit parts of the business that we're commoditizing and focusing our R&D in areas where we can get the kind of returns on performance-driven products. So that's where we've suffered the headwind and it provided a dampening effect over the last year in particular. My sense is based on what I hear from customers, what I hear -- what our business units are predicting, is that and the latter half of this year, we'll be back into, I think, a pretty solid growth pattern with regard to automotive in general across all those 3 sectors.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tore Svanberg with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tore Svanberg with Stifel.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about order rates in your B&B business being stable in spite of the macro climate. Could you talk a little bit more about sort of the linearity of those bookings? Are they calling in sort of in line of seasonal patterns? Or is there any trends
componenttext: You talked about order rates in your B&B business being stable in spite of the macro climate. Could you talk a little bit more about sort of the linearity of those bookings? Are they calling in sort of in line of seasonal patterns? Or is there any trends for strengthening or weakening as we look forward?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tore, thanks. This is Ali. I'll take this one. I think, if you look at the order patterns throughout the quarter, I think they generally trended again ex the consumer business, I'm talking about the B2B business. They generally trended as we would have ex
componenttext: Tore, thanks. This is Ali. I'll take this one. I think, if you look at the order patterns throughout the quarter, I think they generally trended again ex the consumer business, I'm talking about the B2B business. They generally trended as we would have expected them to. It's in November and December we're pretty stable. January saw some pretty good strength. I'd say part of that is just the natural cycle there. January tends to be a stronger order flow month than December. So it was because less holidays. Part of it could be there is -- our first and second quarters had the effect of the Lunar New Year as part of that could be that as well. But I'd say overall, as we now look into February, orders continue to maintain themselves. I'd say when you look at the various businesses, the industrial business is hanging in February to January rates. The Comms business is off a little bit in January rates again, January was strong for the Comms business, particularly as you think about some of these wireless infrastructure build outs in China, likely some ordering that happened in the month in January that was likely going to be consumed in February. So I think overall, I'd say it's probably tracking to where we would expect it to be around this time of year and I think that's certainly implicated in the guidance that we gave for the B2B markets to be in the mid to high single digits sequentially in the second quarter.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to actually follow up on that. So you're guiding the B2B up mid to high single digits, you're sort of calling in seasonal. But I think industrial and auto are typically up in the low double digits sequentially in Q2. So is there something else goin
componenttext: I want to actually follow up on that. So you're guiding the B2B up mid to high single digits, you're sort of calling in seasonal. But I think industrial and auto are typically up in the low double digits sequentially in Q2. So is there something else going on for example in Comms that's offsetting? Or I mean, can you give us some feeling for -- I guess variation across the 3 B2B businesses above or below that average? Because it does seem overall, you're a bit below normal seasonal for industrial and auto?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So we actually went back and looked at the kind of the B2B total and by piece. Communications tends not to have as much seasonal effect and it's more kind of a cycle effect. But when you look at the industrial and automotive, you're right, Stacy. S
componenttext: Right. So we actually went back and looked at the kind of the B2B total and by piece. Communications tends not to have as much seasonal effect and it's more kind of a cycle effect. But when you look at the industrial and automotive, you're right, Stacy. Sometimes, it's in the double digits. Sometimes, it's in the high single digits. Kind of depends on the year. I think partly it depends on where Lunar New Year kind of falls and sometimes Lunar New Year is in the first quarter and sometimes it's in the second quarter. And so I think a little bit of the effect of perhaps us being on the lower end of seasonality in those businesses is the fact that Lunar New Year shows up in the second quarter this time around. Part of it is just you had to pay attention to what's going on in the macro environment. And I think we're being prudently cautious given some of the prohibitions out there, things going on in China, things going on with our customers who's selling into the oil and gas space. So I think there's a little bit of prudence there. And then partly, I think Comms had a pretty good quarter in the first quarter. It's going to probably have kind of a more flattish to up slightly kind of quarter in the second quarter and that would mute the B2B sequential growth rate as well. But overall, I would say we're kind of pretty pleased with how the B2B business has been operating. It had a better than expected first quarter and so to have the second quarter be a little bit on the lower end of seasonality is I think a pretty good outcome.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Just some more color on the consumer end market. How do you expect that to trend this year? Have you seen any change to your forecast recently? And do you think consumer revenue in the second half of calendar '16 will be above or below what it was in the second half of calendar '15?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tough to call the year-over-year growth rate for some. Obviously, we have a good position, I think in the consumer space, particularly in affordable electronic space. We obviously had a really good second half last year. But as the first half of this year
componenttext: Tough to call the year-over-year growth rate for some. Obviously, we have a good position, I think in the consumer space, particularly in affordable electronic space. We obviously had a really good second half last year. But as the first half of this year has shown, it looks like some of that was not real end demand. And so there might have been a little bit of build inventory, some inventory build in the second half of last year that were now feeling the effects of this year. So clearly, on a sequential basis, the second half should be quite strong relative to the first half. I'm not sure how things will work out year-over-year, kind of given that inventory build.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want ask question. I want to go back to the non consumer or B2B business. And if you look at that revenue over a longer period of time, it sort of peaked out in the October '14 quarter at about $720 million. And even against sort of your guide for April
componenttext: I want ask question. I want to go back to the non consumer or B2B business. And if you look at that revenue over a longer period of time, it sort of peaked out in the October '14 quarter at about $720 million. And even against sort of your guide for April, you're still going to be $30 million to $40 million below that level. And Vince, I think in the prior question, you did a good job kind of talking about the puts and takes in autos. I'm assuming industrial military is really a reflection of just kind of a lackluster macro. I guess my question is more on the Comms side of the business which is still down the most over that period of time. Wondering kind of where you think we are in the Comms cycle? Do we get back north of $200 million in revenue at some point? Are there structural barriers to get there? And importantly, if you give us an update on how Hittite is performing within that division, that will be helpful because I believe October '14 was the first full quarter of Hittite revenue?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think the situation in the Communications Infrastructure market is really about -- last year was driven by -- the downturn was driven largely by what was happening in China with regard to regulatory issues, if you like. What we're seeing -- so w
componenttext: Yes. So I think the situation in the Communications Infrastructure market is really about -- last year was driven by -- the downturn was driven largely by what was happening in China with regard to regulatory issues, if you like. What we're seeing -- so we came up a very, very low bottom at the very early part of 2015. But my sense is now with -- we're seeing some bookings momentum. My sense is that we will see a pretty good growth here overall this year in Communications Infrastructure. There's a lot of innovation still taking place. And we are, I believe, gaining share across the board. Our customers are still driving hard in the wireless area, for example, to increase spectral efficiency, reduce power costs, and so on and so forth, in the radio systems. And we're right at the heart of that. The combination of ADI with Hittite makes us, if you like, the Supplier of Choice on a customers thinking of that physical interface between the air and the bits, if you like. So we're very, very happy with what we're seeing in terms of the revenue contribution from Hittite. In fact, in the past quarter, Hittite was up over the same quarter in the prior year. So I think overall, that's going well, in terms of the revenue and profit contribution, in terms of the contribution in improving ADI's capacity to innovate in these radio systems, in 4G. And we're also now starting to get involved in producing, if you like, the architectures for 5G. But my sense is there's still a lot of legs in 4G. And from our perspective, what we're doing is driving technology and product leadership at key customers and so I think this year will be about what the market does and the indications are that the market is going back into a pretty modest bi-mode, I think. And, as I said, we have some very, very good momentum in terms of design-ins across the globe which could bode well for '17 and beyond.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Craig Ellis with B. Riley.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: I have a follow-up on the industrial end market. It looks like it's performing seasonally but from some of the other companies in this sector, we've heard about some weakness in certain geographies like China. So can you address the trends that you're seeing across your major geographies in that key end market? Thank you.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, from a geographic perspective, I would say the -- if you talk about the industrial space specifically, actually we had -- the strongest growth we had was in China last quarter. And Europe was the area of slowest growth. So I think it's a case of the
componenttext: Well, from a geographic perspective, I would say the -- if you talk about the industrial space specifically, actually we had -- the strongest growth we had was in China last quarter. And Europe was the area of slowest growth. So I think it's a case of the macro, the situation in regard to oil exploration has really impacted the situation in America, and to some extent, Europe. But from our perspective, China was the area of strongest performance in the first quarter.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess have a question with gross margin line. I fully understand you guys had a fair bit of deleverage sequentially. But I'm wondering if there were any other factors that played to the margin shortfall that you guys had on a sequential basis? And if yo
componenttext: I guess have a question with gross margin line. I fully understand you guys had a fair bit of deleverage sequentially. But I'm wondering if there were any other factors that played to the margin shortfall that you guys had on a sequential basis? And if you can specifically just maybe quantify the inventory reserves that you had to take on the consumer side?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as you pointed out, I think we exited the fourth quarter around 66% gross margins. It came down to a little over 62%. About half of that was the fact that we lowered utilization in the fab and obviously, when we do that, that has a pretty meaningf
componenttext: Yes, so as you pointed out, I think we exited the fourth quarter around 66% gross margins. It came down to a little over 62%. About half of that was the fact that we lowered utilization in the fab and obviously, when we do that, that has a pretty meaningful effect to the gross margin and then the other half was inventory reserves. And the inventory reserves were specific to the consumer portable electronic business. We built-up inventory to meet what we thought would be backlog in the first and partially, second quarter. And as that forecast was taken down by the customer, we were left with more inventory than we needed in the short term. And so we elected to reserve that inventory for that reason.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis with Berkeley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis with Berkeley.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on that, Dave. When you look at the consumer business, it's obviously down a lot more than others levered to that customer. Can you just talk about within the supply chain, and you mentioned writing off some of your own inventory.
componenttext: I just want to follow up on that, Dave. When you look at the consumer business, it's obviously down a lot more than others levered to that customer. Can you just talk about within the supply chain, and you mentioned writing off some of your own inventory. But when you look at the supply chain, was there inventory in that supply chain that you're working through, if you can talk about yields within the models that your product goes through and is that cleared up as you look at April at such that you could see an uptick in July as you saw last year?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that what we're relatively new product. And I think when that happens, I think the whole supply chain probably adds a bit of cushion along the way to make sure that they can all meet the demand. And of course, the [indiscernible] cust
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that what we're relatively new product. And I think when that happens, I think the whole supply chain probably adds a bit of cushion along the way to make sure that they can all meet the demand. And of course, the [indiscernible] customer doesn't have absolute certainty in terms of what their end demand might look like and so I'm sure they add a little bit of cushion there. As it turned out, that cushion across the whole supply chain including the cushion we had on our own balance sheet wasn't necessary. And as a result, you have the effect of impact to our top line and the need to reserve some of that inventory for possible disposal. So I think based on what we saw in the first quarter, and based on the fact that there was a bit of demand expected in the back half of the second quarter, kind of a resumption to the order flows, we think that this will be behind us by the end of the second quarter and we'll be back to shipping with consumption.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve [indiscernible] with Raymond.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve [indiscernible] with Raymond.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] for Steve. I had a question on the defense business. So the DoD recently released their 2015 proposal. They [indiscernible] R&D to increase by about 4%. [indiscernible] tie into your own defense business and [indiscernible] back to
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] for Steve. I had a question on the defense business. So the DoD recently released their 2015 proposal. They [indiscernible] R&D to increase by about 4%. [indiscernible] tie into your own defense business and [indiscernible] back to determine whether the growth above or below this amount?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you might think the defense business has actually been performing quite well. In fact, I think in the first quarter, we were up double digits. So we continued to get maybe be a disproportionate amount of as it trickles down to us, the capita
componenttext: Well, I think you might think the defense business has actually been performing quite well. In fact, I think in the first quarter, we were up double digits. So we continued to get maybe be a disproportionate amount of as it trickles down to us, the capital spending that the government allocates to defense. Obviously, I think, anything where the government is adding expense or capital expense to the budgets of defense is going to be a good answer for us. In particular, because I think a lot of what they're doing are these military systems that require a lot of semiconductor, require a lot of electronic content and that obviously is beneficial to us. So we've been very pleased with the performance of the defense business. Obviously, the Hittite acquisition just supercharged for us and has helped us to even better in that market. We're seeing all kinds of opportunities for our military components into that space. But not only that, we're actually figuring out ways to take things in the rest of our business that maybe were more commercial in nature and addressing those, that content of the military business to even grow it faster. So pipeline looks great in that space and I think we'll do very well over the next few years in that market.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the things that's happening in that area is the mass digitization of a lot of old radio and microwave systems. So there's a huge cycle of upgrades that is in play and that will continue, we believe, for the next several years. So as Dave said, the
componenttext: One of the things that's happening in that area is the mass digitization of a lot of old radio and microwave systems. So there's a huge cycle of upgrades that is in play and that will continue, we believe, for the next several years. So as Dave said, the combination of ADI's mixed-signal technologies combined with Hittite's microwave products puts us in very, very good stead. And we're certainly seeing that in terms of the business growth in Aerospace & Defense over the last 12 or 18 months and we expect it to be a good contributor to the industrial story over the coming years as well.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great job on the OpEx controls over the past few quarters. How should we think about OpEx beyond fiscal Q2?
componenttext: Great job on the OpEx controls over the past few quarters. How should we think about OpEx beyond fiscal Q2?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we indicated in the prepared remarks, we do expect it to go up a little bit in the second quarter. The second and third quarter gets the impact of salary increases. And so there's kind of a natural lift although it's not significant in the second
componenttext: Well, as we indicated in the prepared remarks, we do expect it to go up a little bit in the second quarter. The second and third quarter gets the impact of salary increases. And so there's kind of a natural lift although it's not significant in the second and third quarter. But it will happen. After that, I think we're going to be very cautious about how we deploy capital and operating expenses until we're really clear on what the macro environment looks like. And so as we came into this year, Vince really set that [indiscernible]. But we basically are going to kind of keep the pie the same and will divide the pie differently based on the markets and product areas that we think are, have the best opportunity for return and I think that's kind of going to be the mindset for us for the foreseeable future unless things kind of change dramatically on the macro side.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from CJ [indiscernible] with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from CJ [indiscernible] with Evercore ISI.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a follow-up question on the inventory reserve and gross margins. Did you take reserve for your inventory or for inventory at ODMs? Part B, I guess, is that inventory now obsolete? Or could it be a tailwind to gross margin in the back half of the y
componenttext: I guess a follow-up question on the inventory reserve and gross margins. Did you take reserve for your inventory or for inventory at ODMs? Part B, I guess, is that inventory now obsolete? Or could it be a tailwind to gross margin in the back half of the year? And then lastly, in terms of getting back to prior peak gross margin last year, 66.5%, what kind of step up in utilization do we need to see? Thank you.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so three-part question. Good. Yes, first of all, on the inventory side. That inventory is not necessarily obsolete. So it's possible it could be used in the future. What was the first -- what was the other part of that specific question on the reser
componenttext: Okay, so three-part question. Good. Yes, first of all, on the inventory side. That inventory is not necessarily obsolete. So it's possible it could be used in the future. What was the first -- what was the other part of that specific question on the reserve?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Were you taking reserves for your own inventory? Or inventory at your key ODMs?
componenttext: Were you taking reserves for your own inventory? Or inventory at your key ODMs?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, once it ships out, it's not our inventory anymore. So we don't take reserves on that. This inventory was in our balance sheet. It was in our supply chain. So that's the inventory reserved. It is possible, like you said, if demand were to change in th
componenttext: Yes, once it ships out, it's not our inventory anymore. So we don't take reserves on that. This inventory was in our balance sheet. It was in our supply chain. So that's the inventory reserved. It is possible, like you said, if demand were to change in the back half of the year, it's possible that inventory does get sold. I wouldn't rule that out. In terms of the gross margins getting back north of 66%, I think we actually have a great shot at that. We are in certainly, in the first quarter, we are artificially low because where utilizations were and because these inventory reserves. We don't expect the inventory reserve situation to repeat itself in the second quarter. But even the utilization is not up to prior peaks, we are thinking it's going to be in the low -- the high 60s rather. And in fact, we've been in the high 70s in prior periods and that's at least 100 basis point improvement to the gross margins. So I think we have a good path towards getting our gross margins back north of 66% and actually probably in relatively short order.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could give us a sense for how large was your largest customer? And broadly, can you talk about diversification in your consumer business? It's obvious the results and the stock has been extremely volatile. And from our perspective, it
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could give us a sense for how large was your largest customer? And broadly, can you talk about diversification in your consumer business? It's obvious the results and the stock has been extremely volatile. And from our perspective, it's very hard to see whether you can or even want to maintain that socket. You might have it this year, but we don't know what the situation will be next year. So can you just give us some color on how we should think about modeling that volatility in your results? Thanks.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in the first quarter, I don't have the number right in front of me. But I think I'm fairly certain it was below 10%, our largest customer. And then it's a long tail after that. So we're pretty diversified from a customer perspective. I think it's
componenttext: Yes, so in the first quarter, I don't have the number right in front of me. But I think I'm fairly certain it was below 10%, our largest customer. And then it's a long tail after that. So we're pretty diversified from a customer perspective. I think it's a valid question as to do we want this business or not. Sometimes, we think about that ourselves based on The Street reactions. But I would tell you, this has been one of the single most successful products we've ever developed in terms of its return on investment. It was a relatively small amount of R&D investment. We were able to utilize technology that was highly proprietary that really cut -- was at the cutting edge of technology and we're able to redeploy it and kind of customize it to a given customer that really made a difference in their application. And that's kind of our philosophy in consumer and it has always been our philosophy in consumer. And so we're going to continue to do that. There will probably be several different things we would do in the consumer space that will have characteristics like this that require -- that leverage our existing technology and drive great returns. And quite honestly, I think that the long-term shareholders of ADI want us to do that. They want us to drive good return on investment. There may be some volatility that happens from quarter-to-quarter. But over the long run, I think we'll be very happy. One of the things I think we cited was that excluding this pension fund change over that we had in the fourth quarter, we will have generated $1 billion in the last 12 months in cash flow. We would not have gotten there without this thing. So we're all about driving cash flow and maximizing that and helping to maximize return on shareholders and I think that this piece of business and business like this do that.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add that we generate the $1 billion return, $800 [ph] million of that and given where the cash flows are, the yield and the free cash flow somewhere around 6% or 7% which is think 1.5x what the S&P is yielding.
componenttext: And I'll just add that we generate the $1 billion return, $800 [ph] million of that and given where the cash flows are, the yield and the free cash flow somewhere around 6% or 7% which is think 1.5x what the S&P is yielding.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Craig [indiscernible] with.
componenttext: Our next question is from Craig [indiscernible] with.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] calling in for Greg. I have a quick follow-up on the Comms business. It's awesome good growth over the last couple of quarters in the communications side. And now from the earlier comments, your business is taking a pause in April.
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] calling in for Greg. I have a quick follow-up on the Comms business. It's awesome good growth over the last couple of quarters in the communications side. And now from the earlier comments, your business is taking a pause in April. What disability do you have in that business? What are you hearing from customers? And if you can touch upon the trends you seeing by geography for that segment.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't say it's taken a pause. I mean, we do expect it to be flat to up. And so I think certainly, I think as Ali mentioned in his prepared remarks, it's in the nascent part of the recovery. We have a pretty good visibility into the pipeline here
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't say it's taken a pause. I mean, we do expect it to be flat to up. And so I think certainly, I think as Ali mentioned in his prepared remarks, it's in the nascent part of the recovery. We have a pretty good visibility into the pipeline here because the design cycles tend to be a lot longer, particularly in areas like the consumer space. And so we kind of understand where our traction is in this space. And as Vince mentioned earlier, based on the way we read how things are going to transpire, given with the newer technology, technologies that we bring out into the wireless comms base, we think we're going to gain share over the next couple of years. In addition, I think that the market has paused as well. Clearly, it paused significantly in China and there is a real need for higher bandwidth. And as all these devices that we all hold dear to ourselves require more and more data, video driving a lot of it now. And so our expectation is that there will be some capital spent in the wireless infrastructure space. That's what our customers are telling us. That's what their customers are telling them. We're excited about our position in that space. We think that will only strengthen. And so that my guess is it's hard to call this for sure. But my guess is we'll be in a pretty consistent recovery phase over the next 18 months or so. And then, who knows when 5G comes around. But when 5G comes around, I think we're in a better position, particularly given that a lot of that technology requires millimeter wave which is one of the key reasons we acquired Hittite.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think with the market. You've got to take a very long term view to it. The space that we've been innovating in for the last 15, 18 years, as technologies became more and more digital in terms of their communications modalities across the various generat
componenttext: I think with the market. You've got to take a very long term view to it. The space that we've been innovating in for the last 15, 18 years, as technologies became more and more digital in terms of their communications modalities across the various generations. So we are -- we're gaining strength every year in terms of technology and customer penetration. We know for sure that there's going to be more and more demand for spectral efficiency as people use more and more and more mobility, higher bandwidth data streams required. So there will be oscillations quarter on quarter. But overall, we believe it's a terrific space to be in. We're investing to win in that market in the radio space. And as I said, our position gets better year by year in terms of customer penetration and technology and product quality and availability.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vince, one for you on your automotive market, that was very helpful earlier when you gave the splits of your business. If I summarized in a different way, investors seem to be a little bit concerned that the automotive market from a SAR perspective is pea
componenttext: Vince, one for you on your automotive market, that was very helpful earlier when you gave the splits of your business. If I summarized in a different way, investors seem to be a little bit concerned that the automotive market from a SAR perspective is peaking. Can you give us any details if you seeing any evidence of peaking behavior? And then probably more importantly, how do you think of your business being unit driven as far as the unit build in the market versus content driven going forward?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ross, let the take part of that and then I'll turn the rest over to Vince. I think from the SAR perspective, really what we saw towards the end of our fiscal year was China, particularly the premium vehicle market there, weakening. I think what we're seei
componenttext: Ross, let the take part of that and then I'll turn the rest over to Vince. I think from the SAR perspective, really what we saw towards the end of our fiscal year was China, particularly the premium vehicle market there, weakening. I think what we're seeing at this stage is that North America is still continuing to be pretty strong. The European vehicle registrations are continuing to be up. And I think very importantly for ADI is that the premium vehicle market in China seems to be stabilizing right now. So that's sort of a macro view in terms of the SAR. And then just secondly, I'd point out, from another, if you take a sort of from another macro review, as we look at the dealer inventories out there, those are in good shape when you look at again the average age of vehicles, they're above the historical norm. So I would suggest that there still some pent up demand from an SAR perspective. But that's, I guess, what sort of 30,000-foot macro view, what's going on with the SAR and I'll let Vince take the second half.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Maybe just one other piece of additional information, light vehicle sales were strong. As Ali said, the luxury part of the market seems to have at least stabilize maybe stalled a bit. But light vehicle sales have been stronger than expected in both,
componenttext: Yes. Maybe just one other piece of additional information, light vehicle sales were strong. As Ali said, the luxury part of the market seems to have at least stabilize maybe stalled a bit. But light vehicle sales have been stronger than expected in both, certainly, North America and Europe. So part of our -- we were talking earlier just about the diversity of our business. Our business continues to become more diverse as we penetrate Asia more aggressively than we have in the past, building on the strength that we've had traditionally in Europe and America. So I think from our perspective, we've got a stronger portfolio than we've ever had. It's really going to be a case of, from an ADI perspective, how well we penetrate the socket. So irrespective of what happens in terms of SAR, we actually have some good momentum in terms of products and technology which will enable us to get share. So I think it will be a tale of those 2 pieces.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I can just add some examples of the technologies that we're bringing into the market. ADAS systems, as we mentioned in the prepared remarks, were up 22% year-over-year. That today's largely a 24 GB solution and over the next couple of years will be
componenttext: And if I can just add some examples of the technologies that we're bringing into the market. ADAS systems, as we mentioned in the prepared remarks, were up 22% year-over-year. That today's largely a 24 GB solution and over the next couple of years will be in 77 GB solutions that modality rolls out, puts us in very strong position to grow. Powertrain Systems continue to be strong again, as carmakers want to make cars more efficient. And finally, and Infotainment front, that's been a good market for us. I don't know if you notice but last month, we announced the release with Ford Motor Company announcing what we call an A2B bus, which is basically taking very high end audio fidelity and cabin, takes out a bunch of weight of the car, still keeps fantastic audio quality within the vehicle then at the end of the day, it's a cheaper solution for the car manufacturer. So those are just another example of the things that Vince was talking about.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from [indiscernible] from [indiscernible] Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is from [indiscernible] from [indiscernible] Partners.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on the Comms business, 20% off of the prior peak at this point. And as talked about their Comms segment not likely achieving prior peaks in the near future, they talked about FTD in China being a smaller deployment than TDD. So for ADI, I m
componenttext: My question is on the Comms business, 20% off of the prior peak at this point. And as talked about their Comms segment not likely achieving prior peaks in the near future, they talked about FTD in China being a smaller deployment than TDD. So for ADI, I mean, do you have the potential to reach prior peaks with some different exposure then what about perhaps more on the microwave side and what sort of timeframe do you think that could happen?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've got a bigger footprint now than we've ever had. I mean, just the combination of the investments that we've been making for the last several years to make sure that we have the most complete solutions in the radio space combined with the microw
componenttext: Well, we've got a bigger footprint now than we've ever had. I mean, just the combination of the investments that we've been making for the last several years to make sure that we have the most complete solutions in the radio space combined with the microwave technologies that we've acquired through Hittite. So I think there are 3 parts we should think about. One is the macro, the macro cell, the small sell. We believe for example that we will see growth this year in macro cells. It will be relatively modest. We're also very well-positioned in small cells and I think it's becoming pretty clear that in China, China Mobile is going to deploy small cells this year. We have a very strong competitive mode that we've built in the area of software defined transceivers that specifically address the small cell arena. And the point-to-point space is, has been modestly growing, seems to have slowed as of late. But there are the 3 components. And we've got a bigger footprint. We're getting more penetration. I believe, it will be more about market adoptions. And we'll let the carriers do in terms of CapEx on hardware versus other things, more so than what we do. So I think we're well-positioned as growth continues to gain momentum here in that market.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And at that not keeping score, but we are 19% of our peak, not 20%.
componenttext: And at that not keeping score, but we are 19% of our peak, not 20%.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stephen Chin with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Chin with UBS.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vince, I want to drill down a little bit on the distribution channel. Can you discuss the selling, sell through rate [indiscernible] good quarter? And what your expectation is in the current year quarter as well?
componenttext: Vince, I want to drill down a little bit on the distribution channel. Can you discuss the selling, sell through rate [indiscernible] good quarter? And what your expectation is in the current year quarter as well?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take your first stab at that and then I'll let either Vince or Dave come in. When you look at the distributor channel this quarter, inventory on a weeks basis, I think Dave mentioned in his prepared remarks, were 7.5 weeks, which is pretty cons
componenttext: Well, I'll take your first stab at that and then I'll let either Vince or Dave come in. When you look at the distributor channel this quarter, inventory on a weeks basis, I think Dave mentioned in his prepared remarks, were 7.5 weeks, which is pretty consistent over the last several quarters. Deferred revenue, which is a pretty good proxy for inventory in the channel at revenue dollars, was down 1% sequentially. So the channel, I'd say, is behaving itself. I think a lot of the inventory is on the supplier balance sheets and I think folks are doing a good job of managing the actual channel. I think when you look at some of the outlooks painted by some of the larger distributors out there, it appears to be a pretty mixed environment. And of course, if you look at -- that is a proxy for industrial business, as Dave mentioned earlier, we sort of back end of the guidance. Regarding industrial been somewhat of a seasonal range but likely sort of in the low end of that seasonal range. But I do know, Vince, if you want to add anything to that?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what you said is correct in terms of you can take our industrial business as a good proxy for what's happening in the channel. So the book to bill is positive at this point in time. And as Ali said, we've got modest expectations based largely by t
componenttext: I think what you said is correct in terms of you can take our industrial business as a good proxy for what's happening in the channel. So the book to bill is positive at this point in time. And as Ali said, we've got modest expectations based largely by the fact that the macro backdrop is, to say the least, volatile at this point in time.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Lipacis with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Lipacis with Jefferies.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mark Lipacis. Dave, you mentioned you're cautious and there's prohibitions in China. But the orders in the non consumer businesses seem seasonal given the timing of the Lunar New Year. And Vince noted that the China industrial market was the stron
componenttext: This is Mark Lipacis. Dave, you mentioned you're cautious and there's prohibitions in China. But the orders in the non consumer businesses seem seasonal given the timing of the Lunar New Year. And Vince noted that the China industrial market was the strongest industrial markets. I'm trying to reconcile what appears to be seasonal order patterns with your cautiousness. Are customers, or distributors throwing the flag? Or was there some other analysis or signals that's driving your cautiousness? Thank you.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Only the, when I say what prohibition, I mean, what you read in the Wall Street Journal and I think on CNBC more than anything. But certainly, in our -- what we see from an order flow perspective, what leads you to be, feel pretty good about the situation
componenttext: Only the, when I say what prohibition, I mean, what you read in the Wall Street Journal and I think on CNBC more than anything. But certainly, in our -- what we see from an order flow perspective, what leads you to be, feel pretty good about the situation, from a macro perspective, but I just think we've got to be -- we got to recognize that there is uncertainty in the market. I think our customers generally feel the same, feels this uncertainty and just are unsure what the outcome will look like for this year. And the result, I think, when those situations arise, it's best to be on the cautious side of things. And if things turn out to be more positive, that would be great. We'll put the money to work at that point. And if it doesn't, we'll have protected our income statement.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at what our customers are predicting for this point, this year versus the same period last year, there was a lot more caution. I think all the big industrial companies are projecting very, very low single-digit growth or flatness through the y
componenttext: If you look at what our customers are predicting for this point, this year versus the same period last year, there was a lot more caution. I think all the big industrial companies are projecting very, very low single-digit growth or flatness through the year. So you've got to take all that into account when you're trying to run your business here.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Doug Freedman with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Doug Freedman with Sterne Agee.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really relates to your M&A strategy. We've seen in the market's taking a little bit different path towards deals in the semiconductor space, those guys that have chosen to lever up and do things that have not been perceived as well. But is this way int
componenttext: It really relates to your M&A strategy. We've seen in the market's taking a little bit different path towards deals in the semiconductor space, those guys that have chosen to lever up and do things that have not been perceived as well. But is this way into your thinking at all? And can you give us an update on how you view M&A? And what the opportunities you see out there today?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that for us, we have a pretty high bar. We have a high bar in terms of it's got to add innovation that's core to what we do. It's got to hit all -- it's got to have the customer base. It's got to be something that the customer turned around and sa
componenttext: I think that for us, we have a pretty high bar. We have a high bar in terms of it's got to add innovation that's core to what we do. It's got to hit all -- it's got to have the customer base. It's got to be something that the customer turned around and say, we really needed to have that technology. And that's obviously -- you've got check the box on all the financial parameters that we have. And like I said, the bar is pretty high in terms of what we'd like to see from that perspective. And so I think that in that regard, we take a pretty, kind of systematic disciplined approach to it. That's the reason we did Hittite and that's the reason we haven't aggressively tried to find other deals this to fill the coffer with M&A, an M&A pipeline. What we've done is we've been carefully looking. I would tell you that we kick the tires on a lot of different ideas over the last year or so and not one of them has reached the high bar that we set. That's not to say that there won't be one down the road and I think when that happens, we'll go to our shareholders and I think we've given the bar we set, we'll give them a pretty compelling reason as to why we wanted to utilize their precious cash to go do that acquisition. And so I think it will end up being positive received in that case. I think we're doing M&A for the sake of M&A, that's when things tend to turn on you.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tristan with Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tristan with Baird.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sort of follow up to prior question, what's your sense of the timing, sort of [indiscernible] 5G? And what's the percentage content increase that ADI has relative to 4G? And also, what geographies offer the highest growth opportunities for the remaining l
componenttext: Sort of follow up to prior question, what's your sense of the timing, sort of [indiscernible] 5G? And what's the percentage content increase that ADI has relative to 4G? And also, what geographies offer the highest growth opportunities for the remaining leg of 4G growth?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean usually, when you go transition from generation to generation, it's easily in the double digits bomb increase in those transitions. I can't tell you when exactly, 5G will roll out. I'm going to say it's a few years away at this point. There mi
componenttext: Yes, I mean usually, when you go transition from generation to generation, it's easily in the double digits bomb increase in those transitions. I can't tell you when exactly, 5G will roll out. I'm going to say it's a few years away at this point. There might be little pockets of early adoption. But most of that is a couple of years away, I think, for us. But when it comes, we're well-positioned for that. 4G is pretty well, certainly, deployed in North America. Although I think there is areas it needs to be identified. China still has a few things to rollout depending if they have -- they change I think sometimes with their -- would way they want to deploy the technology. But over time, over the next couple of years, they'll be in a good position. The rest of the world is actually outside of maybe a few areas like Korea or something, are actually in pretty all generations, particularly in Europe. And so I think there's a lot of room for 4G deployment before we even get into where the 5G takes us.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: 4G still has a lot of legs. As Dave said, it has been multiple years before 5G comes into play and you might be surprised to know that if you take the typical customer that we have in the base stationary, the macro base station area, the product replenish
componenttext: 4G still has a lot of legs. As Dave said, it has been multiple years before 5G comes into play and you might be surprised to know that if you take the typical customer that we have in the base stationary, the macro base station area, the product replenishment rates of the radio is very frequent. There are many, many new radios developed every month for different regions, different spectral usage and so on and so forth within 4G. So there's a lot of innovation and a lot of edge that we can still bring in terms of technology to 4G. And that's what we're doing. When we make the step to 5G, the frequencies increase, the data rates increase. It's got to be much more spectrally efficient than 4G. It needs lower latency and so on and so forth and all to drive the improved coverage and the quality of service. So when that happens, we will have been at the forefront of helping our customers architect what 5G looks like in terms of the radio. So it will be multiple years. But I'm still bullish on 4G and what we can do in that area in terms of bringing ever-increasing levels of innovation and increasing our footprint there.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from [indiscernible] for Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question is from [indiscernible] for Macquarie.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, the dividend increase that you did is probably the lowest, I think the lowest since 2009. But repurchase at Q1 were at a very high-level. So is there a change in the way you guys kind of view your mix of returning capital? And then on fiscal Q2. Are
componenttext: Dave, the dividend increase that you did is probably the lowest, I think the lowest since 2009. But repurchase at Q1 were at a very high-level. So is there a change in the way you guys kind of view your mix of returning capital? And then on fiscal Q2. Are you going to take any more inventory reserve? Because the gross margin leverage, I guess, is a little bit lower than what I would've thought just given the mix and the ramp in the utilization risk.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, philosophically, I guess at the top, we really want to deploy 80% of our cash back to shareholders. And I think the way we look at it, is we try to maintain a balance. Clearly, the stock has weakened a bit since the peak. And so we recognize that the
componenttext: Yes, philosophically, I guess at the top, we really want to deploy 80% of our cash back to shareholders. And I think the way we look at it, is we try to maintain a balance. Clearly, the stock has weakened a bit since the peak. And so we recognize that the buyback is probably going to be fairly active for at least some period of time. And so I think that is really the primary reason why the dividend increase was smaller because we're trying to maintain the balance to get the return to 80%. I wouldn't read into anything more than that. We do have a stated target that will kind of stay between 5% and 10% a year increases in the dividend. But still stay within that range. But what, as you point, was at low end because we think the buyback will be a bit stronger. From an inventory reserve perspective, we think we've taken care of that situation and that we don't expect that to repeat in the second quarter. I'd say the primary reason why the gross margins haven't, I think, they got up to north of 66% probably in the second quarter last year and the reason there, about 100 basis points below that is because of the utilization levels. We are not ramping the utilization up quite as much this quarter versus last year at this time. And [indiscernible] I think a mix. There are certain things that get done internally, certain things that we leverage outside partners for and the way the revenue's going to fall out, I think, for the second quarter is going to be a little bit more disproportionately to the outside wafers that we get from foundry. And so as a result, we won't be cranking the factory as much in the second quarter. On top of that, we do -- we are focused on the inventory levels of the product we build internally and we didn't want that to get too high. So hopefully, in the third and fourth quarter, this momentum that we think we have in the B2B space continues. That certainly has more wafers manufactured internally. And so we do expect to see the utilization come up over the course of the year and that will, should be a pretty good tailwind to gross margin.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Tore Svanberg with Stifel.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have a quick follow-up. Could you talk a little bit about the thinking behind carrying $1.7 billion of debt?
componenttext: I just have a quick follow-up. Could you talk a little bit about the thinking behind carrying $1.7 billion of debt?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Tore. So when we -- as we came into like that, December month, we knew that we had a $375 million bond that was coming due in April of this year. We also thought that we might be using some of the U.S. cash in the near term for an acquisiti
componenttext: Good question, Tore. So when we -- as we came into like that, December month, we knew that we had a $375 million bond that was coming due in April of this year. We also thought that we might be using some of the U.S. cash in the near term for an acquisition. And the rates were pretty attractive. The market was pretty excited. And we were particularly excited by the fact that we could get 30 year debt in some cases or in some amount at rates that, on a tax affected basis, would be kind of less than the dividend yield. We thought that those things combined, meant that would be a good idea to go into the market, get the cash and be ready. As it turned out, the acquisition that we are thinking about, we didn't end up consummating. We did refinance the bonds that utilize some of the cash that we raised. The rest of it does sit on our balance sheet in the U.S. But I think we will, over time, find very good accretive uses for that cash. It was relatively cheap money. We will look to use it in situations where we need U.S. cash for M&A, where as I've mentioned, we are using some of the cash for buybacks and so that's obviously going to be an accretive use for the cash as well. So it -- in terms of net cash which is the number we are more focused on, we think we'll find ways to kind of bring that down over time. One of the disconnects we have is we generate 2/3 of our cash offshore, a lot of our uses, like some of the M&A and some of -- actually, the buyback activity utilized U.S. cash. And we sometimes need to add leverage to the U.S. balance sheet in order to make that happen and the cash accumulates offshore.

Vince, can you talk a bit just about within the consumer space, how we should think about sort of pricing over time and your ability to bring down cost on your solution that you bring to the consumer market especially as you go into sort of second and third generation products from your customer?

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, John, we are very discriminating in terms of how we play the game everywhere, not just in consumer everywhere but particularly in consumer. We've been very clear that we need to have a strong grasp of the complexity of the application and the qualit
componenttext: Well, John, we are very discriminating in terms of how we play the game everywhere, not just in consumer everywhere but particularly in consumer. We've been very clear that we need to have a strong grasp of the complexity of the application and the quality of the solution that we're bringing. So we're playing really at the high performance edge. There are many, many things we can do. But we are very discriminating about the things we take on and we are -- that's the base which we're playing. So we're leveraging, if you like precision core technology that we sell into many, many different sockets and in many, many different applications. And I think as Ali said earlier, we are -- if we have the right places, we get terrific ROI on the technology that we customize in a particular application space in consumer. So I mean, that's the pieces. That's how we play within that space and we -- when we hit it, we hit it very, very well.

headline: Analog Devices, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Well, thank you, John. Thanks for our call us this morning. After that, I do like this morning call. As a reminder, our second quarter '16 results will be issued Wednesday, May 18, 2016 at 8 a.m. Eastern and the earnings call will begin 2 hours lat
componenttext: Great. Well, thank you, John. Thanks for our call us this morning. After that, I do like this morning call. As a reminder, our second quarter '16 results will be issued Wednesday, May 18, 2016 at 8 a.m. Eastern and the earnings call will begin 2 hours later at 10 a.m. Eastern. So thanks for joining us this morning. We look forward to speaking with you soon. And for those in Massachusetts, enjoy the school vacation week. Thanks.
